questions.question: Which statement regarding non-communicable diseases (NCDs) is correct?

options.A: NCDs are responsible for the least number of deaths worldwide.
options.B: Primordial prevention of NCDs involves early diagnosis and treatment of disease.
options.C: According to the WHO, chronic NCDs have a duration of over three months
options.D: Cardiovascular diseases contribute the least to the global DALY.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) According to the WHO, chronic NCDs have a duration of over three months Diseases: Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs): NCDs are responsible for maximum DALY and deaths worldwide (Option A) . Cardiovascular diseases contribute to maximum DALY (Option D). DALYs represent the total burden of disease, combining years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with disability from the condition. Best Level of Prevention: The best level of prevention for NCDs is primordial prevention. This involves preventing the development of risk factors for NCDs (Option B) . Examples of primordial prevention strategies include promoting healthy diets and physical activity from a young age to prevent obesity and associated NCDs later in life. Chronic NCD Duration: The World Health Organization (WHO) defines a chronic NCD as a disease with a duration of greater than three months (Option C) . This is in contrast to acute diseases, which have a shorter duration. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 26. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3542738/

questions.question: Which of the following is the role of an ASHA worker in the NP-NCD? hospitals.

options.A: Diagnose and initiate treatment for NCDs like diabetes and hypertension at the village level.
options.B: Perform ECGs and other lab investigations at monthly village clinics to screen for NCDs
options.C: Conduct opportunistic screenings for NCDs and refer suspected cases to community health centers.
options.D: Provide specialized care and treatment for cancer patients and refer complicated cases to district

questions.explanation: community health centers. Correct Answer: C) Conduct opportunistic screenings for NCDs and refer suspected cases to community health centers. Explanation: Role of ASHA in NP-NCD: Conducts opportunistic screening of the community for NCDs, including diabetes, risk factors for TB, and other NCDs Uses blood pressure measurement and strip method blood glucose testing to screen individuals over 30 years old for NCDs. Refers suspected cases of diabetes and hypertension to Community Health Centers (CHCs) or higher healthcare facilities for diagnosis and management. Makes home visits to encourage positive behavior modifications, monitor treatment compliance, and encourage patients to attend regular check-ups for blood pressure and blood glucose at sub-centers. Receives I 10 for every Community-Based Assessment Checklist (CBAC) form completed. These forms are used to screen for NCDs, including diabetes, risk factors for TB, and other NCDs. ASHA workers are not qualified to diagnose or initiate treatment for NCDs (Option A). Performing ECGs and other laboratory investigations is beyond the scope of an ASHA worker's role (Option B). They do not provide specialized cancer care or treatment (Option D). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 542.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a target outlined in the WHO's global monitoring framework for the prevention and control of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in India?

options.A: A 5% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity by 2025.
options.B: A 25% relative reduction in premature mortality from NCDs by 2025.
options.C: A 30% relative reduction in the prevalence of current tobacco use by 2025.
options.D: An 80% availability of essential NCD medicines in public and private facilities by 2025.

questions.explanation: 2025. Correct Answer: A) A 5% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity by 2025. Explanation: Global Initiatives to Control NCDs: Initiated by WHO Expected to be achieved by 2025. WHO framework aims for a 10% reduction in insufficient physical activity by 2025, not 15%. (Option A) Targets are: Diabetes/Obesity 0% increase. Harmful use of alcohol- at least 10% reduction. Physical inactivity 10% reduction. (Option A) Premature mortality from NCDs 25% reduction. (Option B) Raised blood pressure by 25% reduction. S alt/ s odium intake 30% reduction. Tobacco use ( S moking) 30% reduction. (Option C) During therapy and counselling - at least 50% coverage Essential NCD medicine and technologies 80% coverage. (Option D) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 542, 543.

questions.question: Which program's logo depicts the integration of cancer control, diabetes management, cardiovascular disease prevention, and stroke management, reflecting its comprehensive approach to combating these interconnected health challenges in India? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Explanation: The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-communicable Diseases (NP-NCD) is explicitly described as an integrated program. It combines efforts to address cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke, making it the most suitable program with a logo reflecting this integrated approach. Component Initiatives New Initiatives under NP-NCD Intervention for prevention and control of Rheumatic Heart Disease under NP-NCD and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK). Integration of AYUSH with NP-NCD. Integration of RNTCP with NP-NCD to articulate a national strategy for management of TB and diabetes comorbidities in India. Cancer Component under NP-NCD Cancer Services under NP-NCD: Providing common diagnostic services, basic surgery, chemotherapy, and palliative care for cancer patients at 100 district hospitals. Supporting each district with chemotherapy drugs for 100 patients, establishing day-care chemotherapy facilities, and providing facilities for laboratory investigations, including mammography. Offering home-based palliative care for chronic and progressive cancer patients in 100 districts. Designating State Cancer Institutes (SCIs) as apex institutions for comprehensive cancer diagnosis, treatment, and care. Strengthening 45 centres as Tertiary Cancer Centres (TCCs) to deliver comprehensive cancer care services. Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) logo ( Option A). National Programme for Health Care of the Elderly (NPHCE) logo ( Option B). Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) logo ( Option D). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 542, 543.

questions.question: Which of the following obesity indicators is considered the most useful single measurement for assessing central obesity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Waist circumference Explanation: Obesity can be defined as abnormal growth of adipose tissue, which may be due to an increase in fat cell size or number. Indicators of obesity: Body weight: BMI (Quetele’s index): weight (kg) / height (m²) Ponderal index: height (cm)/cube root of body weight Broca’s index: height (cm) -100 Corpulence index: Actual weight / desirable weight Lorentz formula: II Though not accurate, body weight is the most commonly used indicator of obesity BMI is the most widely used indicator worldwide. Does not differentiate between fat and muscle mass. Also, does not provide information regarding fat distribution (Option A) . Skinfold thickness: The sum of all four measurements: >40 in males and >50 in females Rapid and non-invasive method for measuring body fat. Measured with Harpenden skin callipers Measurements taken at: mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions Measures subcutaneous fat (Option B) Waist circumference: >102 cm in males and >88 cm in females In the Indian population, >90 cm in males and >80 cm in females is considered high risk. Measured at midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. Correlates closely with BMI Most commonly used to measure central obesity and its associated risk factors (Option C) Directly related to cardiovascular and other chronic diseases Waist to hip ratio >1 in men and >0.85 in females Correlates with waist circumference There may be some discrepancies as the body fat distribution may be different for each individual (Option D) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 454, 455

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding diabetes mellitus? ≥ 6 mmol/L ≥ 200 mg/dL ≥ 11.1 mmol/L

options.B: 2 hour post load capillary plasma glucose should be

questions.explanation: ≥ 11.1 mmol/L Correct Answer: C) Random plasma glucose should be ≥ 11.1 mmol/L Explanation: Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder identified by the presence of hyperglycemia in the absence of treatment. Diagnostic criteria for DM: According to WHO Measurement Diagnostic cut-off value Fasting plasma glucose ≥ 7 mmol/L (126 mg/dL) (Option A) 2 hour post load venous plasma glucose ≥ 11.1 mol/L (200 mg/dL) 2 hour post load capillary plasma glucose ≥ 12.2 mmol/L (220 mg/dL) (Option B) Random plasma glucose ≥ 11.1 mmol/L (200 mg/dL) (Option C) HbA1c ≥ 6.5% (Option D) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 450

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding HTN? adulthood. alone.

options.A: A BP of 146/92 is considered a Grade I HTN.
options.B: On tracking of HTN, a person who is hypotensive in childhood then remains hypotensive in
options.C: Only half of all hypertensive patients need lifelong medication; others manage with lifestyle changes
options.D: Weight loss is the single most beneficial lifestyle modification done to manage HTN.

questions.explanation: with lifestyle changes alone. Correct Answer: C) Only half of all hypertensive patients need lifelong medication; others manage with lifestyle changes alone. Explanation: Hypertension is a chronic condition defined as an increase in blood pressure. Classification of HTN: Category Systolic BP (mm Hg) Diastolic BP (mm Hg) Optimal <120 <80 Normal <130 <85 High normal 130-139 85-89 Grade I 140-159 (Option A) 90-99 Grade II 160-179 100-109 Hypertensive crisis ≥ 180 >110 Tracking of Hypertension: If blood pressure is tracked from childhood over a period of years, then hypotensive children tend to remain hypotensive in adulthood, and hypertensive children tend to remain hypertensive in adulthood (Option B). This phenomenon is useful in identifying at-risk children and planning for adequate management of HTN. Rules of Halves (Option C): The concept of the "Rule of Halves" in hypertension management illustrates that: Approximately 50% of individuals with hypertension are aware of their condition. Among those aware, only about 50% receive treatment. Out of those receiving treatment, approximately 50% have their blood pressure adequately controlled. Lifestyle modifications: Modification Approx. SBP reduction Weight loss 5-20 mmHg/10 kg weight loss (Option D) DASH diet 8-14 mmHg Dietary sodium reduction 2-8 mmHg Physical activity 4-9 mmHg Moderation of alcohol 2-4 mmHg Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 425-429
